facts.text: Sabir was murdered on the 11th May 1951 at about 6-30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which have given rise to the appeal are that Sabir was murdered on the 11th May, 195 1, at about 6-30 p.m.

facts.text: First Information Report was made by Qudrat Ullah at 6-45 p.m. on the same day within about 15 minutes of the occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: The First Information Report was made by Qudrat Ullah the other accused at 6-45 p.m. the same day, i.e., within about 15 minutes of the occurrence.

facts.text: There was an exchange of abuses between the deceased Sabir and the appellant near the shop of Qudrat Ullah.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that there was an exchange of abuses between the deceased and the appellant near the shop of the First Informant, Qudrat Ullah.

facts.text: Cause of quarrel: on the evening of the occurrence, deceased asked appellant why he was in such a dishevelled condition, annoying the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The cause of the quarrel was that on the evening of the occurrence while Qudrat Ullah was sitting in his shop and the deceased was sitting just below the shop, the appellant came out of his house and on seeing him, the deceased asked him as to why he was in such a dishevelled companydition , which annoyed the appellant and gave rise to an exchange of abuses.

facts.text: Prosecution witnesses arrived at the spot and saw the appellant and the deceased grappling with each other.

anchor.surface_text: On hearing this numberse, the prosecution witnesses arrived at the spot and saw the appellant and the deceased grappling with each other.

facts.text: Appellant asked Qudrat Ullah to hand over a knife, which Qudrat Ullah did, and appellant stabbed the deceased with it then fled away.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is stated to have asked Qudrat Ullah to hand over a knife to him which Qudrat Ullah did this knife is Ex. I II, with which the appellant stabbed the deceased and then fled away.

facts.text: Deceased fell down in front of Qudrat Ullah's shop as a result of the injuries.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the injuries the deceased fell down infront of Qudrat Ullahs shop some witnesses have stated that he fell on the wooden plank in front of the shop.

facts.text: Qudrat Ullah picked up the knife dropped by the appellant, put the deceased in a rickshaw, took him to the hospital, then went to Police Station and made FIR.

anchor.surface_text: Qudrat Ullah picked up the knife which had been dropped by the appellant, put the deceased in a rickshaw and took him to the hospital from where he went to the Police Station and made the First Information Report.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector went to the spot, started investigation and arrested the appellant the same evening at his house.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Inspector went to the spot, started investigation and arrested the appellant the same evening at his house.

facts.text: Postmortem showed injuries on deceased; death due to shock and haemorrhage from punctured wound in chest injuring lungs, caused by sharp-edged weapon.

anchor.surface_text: The postmortem examination of the deceased showed injuries on the person of the deceased and, according to the doctor., death was due to shock and haemorrhage on account of the punctured wound in the chest, causing injuries to the lungs and these injuries companyld be caused with a sharp-edged weapon.

facts.text: Appellant and deceased both belong to a sect of Jogis and were quite friendly with each other.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the deceased both belong to a sect of Jogis. Evidence discloses that the deceased and the appellant were quite friendly with each other

facts.text: Qudrat Ullah is a butcher with shop which is part of his house; adjacent to appellant's house.

anchor.surface_text: , and so were the deceased and Qudrat Ullah, who is a butcher and had a shop which is a part of his house. Adjacent to the shop is the house of the appellant.

facts.text: Eyewitnesses: Yad Ali PW1, Banne PW2, Mohd. Ahmed PW3 saw the grappling, knife handover, stabbing.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of Yad Ali P. W. 1, is that he heard an exchange of abuses between the deceased and the appellant and when he moved about 4 or 5 paces he saw them grappling with each other. The appellant had the deceased ,in his grip, he asked Qudrat Ullah to hand over a knife to him which the latter did and with it the appellant stabbed the deceased and then went away to his house. The statement of Banne is similar and so is the statement of Mohd. Ahmed, P. W. 3.

facts.text: Sessions Judge Bareilly acquitted both accused on July 8, 1952 in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 27 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated July 8, 1952, of the Court of Sessions Judge at Bareilly in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 27 of 1952. Daulat Ram Prem and P. C. Agarwala, for the appellant, Gyan Chand Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the respondent.

facts.text: State appealed to Allahabad High Court against appellant only in Government Appeal No. 60 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: But the State took an appeal to the Allahabad High Court against the appellant only and the judgment of acquittal in his case was reversed

facts.text: Allahabad High Court on October 18, 1955 reversed acquittal, convicted appellant under s.302 IPC, sentenced to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated October 18, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Government Appeal No. 60 of 1953

facts.text: Supreme Court Criminal Appeal No. 150 of 1956 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 150 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated October 18, 1955,

facts.text: High Court acquitted Qudrat Ullah implicitly by rejecting evidence of his involvement.

anchor.surface_text: It held We may companycede that the eye-witnesses have falsely implicated Qudrat Ullah by deposing that he handed over his knife to the respondent on his demand. There was numberenmity between him and Sabir and he bad numbermotive to get him killed by the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld the conviction of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Upon a review of the evidence of the prosecution witnesses we have companye ,to the companyclusion that the appellant was rightly companyvicted.

facts.text: Shakir PW5 heard abuses but went to fill chillum at Qudrat's request, returned to find deceased unconscious and appellant running away.

anchor.surface_text: Shakir, P.W. 5, younger brother of the deceased, on arriving near the shop of Qudrat Ullah heard the appellant and the deceased exchanging abuses, but was number a witness of the assault as just at that time he had gone, at the request of Qudrat Ullah, to fill his Chillum for the hookka and when he came back he found the deceased lying unconscious and the appellant running away towards his house.

facts.text: Ashraft PW4 arrived later, found deceased lying unconscious after being told by deceased's sister.

anchor.surface_text: Having been told by the sister of the deceased as to the occurrence, Ashraft, P.W. 4 came to the spot later and found the deceased lying unconscious.

facts.text: Knife used is Ex. I II.

anchor.surface_text: which Qudrat Ullah did this knife is Ex. I II, with which the appellant stabbed the deceased

facts.text: Sessions Judge did not accept eyewitness evidence and acquitted both.

anchor.surface_text: This evidence was number accepted by the learned Sessions Judge and he acquitted both the accused.

facts.text: High Court found no doubt about appellant's guilt and rebutted presumption of innocence.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the prosecution has fully established the, case against the respondent. There is number the slightest doubt about his guilt. The presumption of innocence has been fully rebutted by the prosecution.

issues.text: Whether the First Information Report made by co-accused Qudrat Ullah is admissible as substantive evidence against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: An objection has been taken to the admissibility of this report as it was made by a person who was a co-accused. A First Information Report is not a substantive piece of evidence and can only be used to corroborate the statement of the maker under s. 157 of the Evidence Act or to contradict it under s.

issues.text: Whether the High Court's observation shifted the burden of proof to the accused in violation of the presumption of innocence

anchor.surface_text: There is a passage in the Judgment of the High Court which appears to us to be disconsolate and indicative of a wrong approach in deciding the guilt of an accused person. Although the learned Judges recognised the principle that the onus was not on the accused, yet one of the observations is such that it comes perilously near to putting - the burden on the accused if it does not actually do so. The High Court has said The respondent himself did not have the courage to say that he did not find them at the spot. If he were innocent, he must have come out -of his house immediately on hearing the noise and must have known who was present there and who was not This passage is so destructive of the cardinal principle of criminal jurisprudence as to the presumed innocence of an accused person till otherwise proved that it has become necessary to reiterate the rule stated by eminent authorities that it is the duty of the prosecution to prove the prisoners guilt subject to any statutory exception.

issues.text: Whether the maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is a mandatory rule of evidence requiring rejection of the entire testimony of witnesses if part of it is disbelieved

anchor.surface_text: it was next contended that the witnesses had falsely implicated Qudrat Ullah and because of that the Court should have rejected the testimony of these witnesses as against the appellant also. The well-known maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus was relied upon by the appellant. The argument raised was that because the witnesses who had -also deposed against Qudrat Ullah by saying that he had handed over the knife to the appellant had not been believed by the Courts below as against him, the High Court should not have accepted the evidence of these witnesses to convict the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in reversing the Sessions Judge's acquittal of the appellant on the ground that it was a view no reasonable person could take

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges also came to the conclusion that the view taken by the learned trial Judge was one which no reasonable person could have taken. It was a wholly erroneous view of the evidence which has resulted in gross miscarriage of justice inasmuch as a murderer escapes punishment.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution evidence proves the guilt of the appellant under s. 302 IPC beyond reasonable doubt

arguments.claim: Eyewitnesses falsely implicated Qudrat Ullah as there was no enmity or motive and his conduct after incident inconsistent with guilt

anchor.surface_text: It held We may concede that the eye-witnesses have falsely implicated Qudrat Ullah by deposing that he handed over his knife to the respondent on his demand. There was no enmity between him and Sabir and he had no motive to get him killed by the respondent. It does not at all appear probable that after abetting the murder of Sabir he at once took him on a rickshaw to the hospital and from there went at once to the police station and lodged a report against the respondent.

arguments.claim: Maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus is merely a rule of caution, not mandatory rule of evidence

anchor.surface_text: This maxim has not received general acceptance in different jurisdictions in India nor has this maxim come to occupy the status of a rule of law. It is merely a rule of caution. All that it amounts to is that in such cases the testimony may be disregarded and not that it must be disregarded.

holdings.text: A First Information Report is not a substantive piece of evidence and can only be used to corroborate the statement of the maker under s. 157 of the Evidence Act or to contradict it under s. 145 of that Act. It cannot be used as evidence against the maker at the trial if he himself becomes an accused, not to corroborate or contradict other witnesses. In this case, therefore, it is not evidence.

anchor.surface_text: A First Information Report is not a substantive piece of evidence and can only be used to corroborate the statement of the maker under s. 157 of the Evidence Act or to contradict it under s. 145 of that Act. -It cannot be used as evidence against the maker at the trial if he himself becomes an accused, number to corroborate or contradict other witnesses. In this case, therefore, it is number evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies provisions of Evidence Act ss.157 and 145 limiting FIR to corroboration or contradiction of its maker only, explicitly excluding use as substantive evidence against co-accused or others.

holdings.text: The High Court observation comes perilously near to putting the burden on the accused; it is the duty of the prosecution to prove the prisoner's guilt subject to any statutory exception.

anchor.surface_text: There is a passage in the Judgment of the High Court which appears to us to be disconsolate and indicative of a wrong approach in deciding the guilt of an accused person. Although the learned Judges recognised the principle that the onus was number on the accused, yet one of the observations is such that it companyes perilously near to putting - the burden on the accused if it does number actually do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Identifies flawed reasoning in High Court judgment perilously close to shifting burden, reiterates cardinal principle citing Woolmington v. DPP that prosecution bears burden of proof on guilt.

holdings.text: The maxim falsus in uno falsus in omnibus has not received general acceptance in India nor occupies status of rule of law; it is merely a rule of caution whereby testimony may be disregarded but not that it must be.

anchor.surface_text: This maxim has number received general acceptance in different jurisdictions in India number has this maxim companye to occupy the status of a rule of law. It is merely a rule of caution. All that it amounts to is that in such cases the testimony may be disregarded and number that it must be disregarded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects maxim as mandatory evidence rule based on lack of acceptance in Indian jurisdictions, cites authorities like Wigmore deeming it superfluous and pernicious; permits partial acceptance of testimony.

holdings.text: The view taken by the Sessions Judge was one which no reasonable person could have taken, resulting in gross miscarriage of justice; High Court justified in reversing acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges also came to the companyclusion that the view taken by the learned trial Judge was one which numberreasonable person companyld have taken. It was a wholly erroneous view of the evidence which has resulted in gross miscarriage of justice inasmuch as a murderer escapes punishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Wednesbury unreasonableness test to trial judge's perverse view of evidence leading to miscarriage; appellate interference warranted when acquittal grossly erroneous.

holdings.text: Upon review of prosecution evidence, appellant rightly convicted under s.302 IPC as eyewitness testimony establishes guilt beyond reasonable doubt despite minor discrepancies and rejection of part implicating Qudrat Ullah.

anchor.surface_text: Upon a review of the evidence of the prosecution witnesses we have companye ,to the companyclusion that the appellant was rightly companyvicted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independently reviews eyewitness accounts (PW1,2,3), medical evidence, prompt FIR, rejects defence improbabilities as insufficient to discredit core reliable testimony proving stabbing by appellant.
